articles.headline: China’s Leaders Confront Their Manic Market
articles.snippet: China’s bigger challenges lie in how to rein in the soaring stock market and whom to pick as the next governor of the central bank.
articles.abstract: China’s bigger challenges lie in how to rein in the soaring stock market and whom to pick as the next governor of the central bank.

articles.headline: In Need of Income, Cemeteries Are Seeking Breathing Clientele
articles.snippet: Historic cemeteries, in need of money for restorations, are reaching out to the public in unusual ways.
articles.abstract: Historic cemeteries, in need of money for restorations, are reaching out to the public in unusual ways.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — The dinner was first-class, with butlers serving hors d’oeuvres and the strains of “Blue Danube” tastefully muffling the festive din. This nine-course re-creation of the last supper aboard an ill-fated ocean liner was the culmination of Titanic Day at Laurel Hill Cemetery, one of a growing number of historic cemeteries to rebrand themselves as destination necropolises for weekend tourists.

articles.headline: Immigration Bill Provisions Gain Wide Support in Poll
articles.snippet: Americans want to allow illegal immigrants to gain legal status and to create a guest worker program, a Times/CBS News poll found.
articles.abstract: Americans want to allow illegal immigrants to gain legal status and to create a guest worker program, a Times/CBS News poll found.
articles.lead_paragraph: As opponents from the right and left challenge an immigration bill before Congress, there is broad support among Americans — Democrats, Republicans and independents alike — for the major provisions in the legislation, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.
articles.byline: By Julia Preston and Marjorie Connelly

articles.headline: Coca-Cola Is Said to Buy Vitaminwater
articles.snippet: Coca-Cola’s directors approved the purchase of Glaceau, the maker of Vitaminwater, for $4.2 billion.
articles.abstract: Coca-Cola’s directors approved the purchase of Glaceau, the maker of Vitaminwater, for $4.2 billion.
articles.lead_paragraph: Directors of the Coca-Cola Company last night approved the purchase of Glaceau, the maker of Vitaminwater, for $4.2 billion in cash and Coke stock, according to an executive involved in the negotiations.
articles.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Andrew Martin

articles.headline: Risky Bets on Winning Tax Fights
articles.snippet: American public companies are betting billions on tax breaks that may not work out.
articles.abstract: American public companies are betting billions on tax breaks that may not work out.
articles.lead_paragraph: Death may still be certain, but taxes are something else entirely.

articles.headline: Investigation Is Said to Open on Dow Chemical
articles.snippet: The S.E.C. has begun an inquiry into whether two senior executives  secretly tried to put the company into play.
articles.abstract: The S.E.C. has begun an inquiry into whether two senior executives  secretly tried to put the company into play.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Securities and Exchange Commission has begun an inquiry into whether two senior executives at Dow Chemical secretly tried to put the company into play as well as into the unusual trading in its stock that may have resulted, according to people briefed on the matter.

articles.headline: More Than Ever, It Pays to Be the Top Executive
articles.snippet: The gap between the chief executive’s pay and the pay of executives a rank or two down is quickly widening.
articles.abstract: The gap between the chief executive’s pay and the pay of executives a rank or two down is quickly widening.
articles.lead_paragraph: Like most companies, Office Depot has long made sure that its chief executive was the highest-paid employee. Ten years ago, the $2.2 million pay package of its chief was more than double that of his No. 2. The fifth-ranked executive received less than one-third.
